subject: meson support: create meson.build files
commitMessage:
meson support: create meson.build files

This commit contains the meson.build files necessary to build the
project and unit tests. The normal procedure is to run the command
'meson build' followed by ninja -C build

Change-Id: I2e525270809fc1a66109479859305e6b2002847f
Signed-off-by: Mike Capps <mikepcapps@gmail.com>

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/46403/ : FAILURE
Please remove all the autotools stuff too.  Just the 3 lines George mentioned is sufficient.
autotools removal is done in a separate commit
Suggest adding this in the root directory's meson.build.

Does `file('control/gen-fan-zone-defs.py')` do this for you?

Ideally all of these would be added to 'depfiles' in the custom_target also so that the dependency is known.
No, I get the error "Unknown function "file"
after some searching I found the files() function, hopefully this will do. If you could elaborate a bit more about the depfile keyword or point me to an example I'd appreciate it.
None of this should be necessary.  Very few of our projects include this verbiage and I'm not sure why any of them do.
More specifically, you should just have `dependency('fmt')` and let the subproject find it if it doesn't exist in the environment.
This should not be necessary.  Will leave comments in subproject as the right fix.
I think as long as it has a disabler, I'm indifferent as to where it goes.  Most of our projects have it in the test/meson.build though.
The convention in meson is that all dependency variables are named foo_dep.  You might revise this in the whole file.
Should not be required.  The 'provide' in the subproject wrap file should take care of this.
Why is this here but line 62 also sets this variable?  This seems error prone.  Please refactor.
Why'd we rename the files and remove the @BINDIR@ support in an earlier commit if we're still using the configure_file directive on them?
it's still a config file, but BINDIR is required for autoconf. so the renaming is done after autoconf removal, else it will not pass CI
Yes.  Please use features on all of this and then simplify the meson.build accordingly.  I think you have excess comparisons with 'false' as a result of picking boolean.

How many of these options are actually useful to have as options?  Does anyone ever change any of them?  If not, I'd suggest using this as an opportunity to change them to static values (direct in meson.build? direct in headers?).

the ones that are dbus related could be moved out with no issues, like the busname and objpath ones.

I think the yaml filenames are all used during the build to specify which config files to use so should stay in here.
Also look at `file` simplification here too.  And add depfiles.
Might boost this up to the parent directory.  Makes it easier to track the dependencies, I think.

Could you add a sources variable to include them?

source = [
    'main.cpp',
    'shutdown_alarm_monitor.cpp',
    'threshold_alarm_logger.cpp',
]

add a deps variable to include them

deps = [
    phosphor_logging_dep,
    sdeventplus_dep,
]

I prefer to do this:
 include_directories: ['..']
More specifically, run `meson wrap install fmt` and it will give you an upstream maintained wrapfile with all the appropriate dependency pieces added.
Do we need .clang-tidy and .clang-format for subproject?
this only runs if in yaml mode, right?
yes, its conditionally-added to the sources below.

This line is the same as conf_data.set(PRESENCE_USE_JSON, 1).
And will create "#define PRESENCE_USE_JSON 1" in config.h.
I think we just need #define PRESENCE_USE_JSON and does not care value of PRESENCE_USE_JSON.
Preference:
https://mesonbuild.com/Configuration.html#configuring-without-an-input-file
Do we really need these kind of options? I think the configuration name files should not be changed.
Don't we need them to pass in the paths during bitbake?
Should we include min, max option for integer build options?
I'm not sure the code cares about the min and the max? I guess at least not negative, but i'm not sure why anyone would try to use that.
Usually, the min, max value as it meaning is used to define the limitation of on configuration option. If this option does not have the limitation then we don't need it.
I think you removed the code in meson.build that was looking at this, so you can remove it from here.
Why wouldn't you create meson build files, then remove autoconf?
Heh... I ended up reviewing these out of order, thinking you would create meson, then remove autoconf, but now I see that comment made in a prior commit.
Originally I wasn't sure which build would be preferred by CI so it was a coin-flip either way 😊

I fail to understand how this builds, if you remove autoconf. I would expect the CI run to do nothing, make nothing, install nothing. You need to add in meson in order to actually build and install the code.

Normally when a repository is changed from autoconf to meson, the meson is added, you can build either way, then autoconf is removed, so you are left with meson only.

There is a circular dependency: autoconf requires the service files to have BINDIR in their name. Meson can NOT have the service files named that way. So I'll either need to squash the service-file rename into the meson.build commit, or else modify autoconf/meson to make a change that is only used to support a single previous commit.
This should be fixed by copying the service files, and removing the extra ones when autoconf is removed.
Why is this dependency unique? The others have that _dep on the end.

Isn't this the default install_dir?  I think there is a preference to put systemd-loaded services into `/var/libexec` (see anti-patterns document in the docs repo for more details), but this can be tackled with another commit since it is not changing from the existing autotools support

I think you misunderstood my earlier comment.

You are using 'configure_file', which typically operates on foo.in files and modifies them with the values of your configuration variables.  

1. Why are we still using configure_file instead of simply installing the service directory?
2. If we need to configure_file, why remove the BINDIR (or meson equivalent support) rather than hard-coding the path in the service.
Also surprised this isn't the default here (and should move to libexec at some point).

Pretty sure this still isn't right.  Earlier I said:

> More specifically, run `meson wrap install fmt` and it will give you an upstream maintained wrapfile with all the appropriate dependency pieces added.

The upstream fmt doesn't support meson by default.  The wrapdb has patches to enable it.
I tried that initially but the command failed with the version of meson I was using. I tried another version and now it works.
We don't have any tests?  Why'd we do so much work to enable google test without any tests defined?

I think the merge conflict is pointing out some kind of re-arrange/squash. https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-fan-presence/+/55105

Is this no longer a change worth reviewing? Abandon, and go look at 55105?
